00041 //      A simple string pattern which represents a reduced set
00042 //      of the standard UNIX regular expression syntax.
00043 //      Currently supported is the single wild-card '*', which
00044 //      matches any number (including zero) of any character.
00045 
00046 class myStringPattern 
00047 {
00048   public:
00049       //        Constructor taking the string pattern.
00050       myStringPattern (const std::string& s);
00051 
00052 
00053       //        Match operation. Returns true if the pattern matched the
00054       //        string.
00055       bool Match (const std::string& s) const;
00056 
00057       //        Operator form of match().
00058       bool operator () (const std::string& s) const;
00059 
00060       //        Outputs to os the original pattern.
00061       friend ostream& operator << (ostream& os, const myStringPattern& pattern);
00062 
00063       operator string () const;
00064 
00065       bool operator < (const myStringPattern& rhs) const;
00066 
00067       bool operator == (const myStringPattern& rhs) const;
00068 
00069     // Data Members for Class Attributes
00070 
00071       //        The wildcard character (default ='*').
00072       static char wcchar;
00073 
00074   protected:
00075   private:
00076     // Data Members for Class Attributes
00077 
00078       //        A vector of literal strings. The pattern is split into
00079       //        literals by the presence of a '*' character.
00080 
00081       std::vector<string> patterns;
00082       //        Used to indicate if the first/last character of the
00083       //        string pattern were wildcards.
00084 
00085       std::pair<bool,bool> wcterm;
00086       //        Set to true if this pattern is a simple literal string
00087       //        (no wild cards).
00088 
00089       bool isLiteral;

00091       std::string str;
00092
